ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course focused on not only comparing modern Japanese and Brazilian novels, but also studying the novels in tandem with particular social & historical contexts, literary movement, and backdrop of individual authors.
Introduction to the modern canons and major authors of Brazilian and Japanese literature

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very good in-class discussion. It could feel a bit awkward sometimes when nobody had anything to say.

Good novels, knowledgable professor, straightforward assignments, low stress
However, at times it could be mostly the professor talking and less discussion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you read through the syllabus and like particular novels or authors. These works are supposed to be representative of modern J and B literature, and the course still has a survey course feel to it, but in-class discussion could certainly be very interesting. For comp lit & humanities people who have to take a course like this, I came in really didnt expect much from this course, but it grew on me and now Im so glad I took it. Prof Jacobowitz is so good at starting and keeping the discussion engaging.
Yes; however, you get as much out as you put in (i.e. you don't have to read very closely, but it is a good selection of books)
